section.heading: Suits against commission and its employees.

content.p: 59-1-1005. Suits against commission and its employees. (1) A taxpayer may bring a civil suit against the commission for recovery of actual damages and costs incurred by the taxpayer if: (a) the commission or one of its employees intentionally or recklessly takes possession of a taxpayer's property in disregard of its published procedures, laws, or rules; or (b) otherwise intentionally or recklessly disregards published procedures, laws, or rules. (2) An award of actual damages and court costs in a suit under this section may not exceed $100,000. (3) If the court finds that the civil action brought by the taxpayer is frivolous, the court may impose a penalty of up to $10,000 against the taxpayer. Amended by Chapter 9 , 2001 General Session
A taxpayer may bring a civil suit against the commission for recovery of actual damages and costs incurred by the taxpayer if:
the commission or one of its employees intentionally or recklessly takes possession of a taxpayer's property in disregard of its published procedures, laws, or rules; or
otherwise intentionally or recklessly disregards published procedures, laws, or rules.
An award of actual damages and court costs in a suit under this section may not exceed $100,000.
If the court finds that the civil action brought by the taxpayer is frivolous, the court may impose a penalty of up to $10,000 against the taxpayer.
